items.content_html: A tax benefit boosted quarterly earnings, but that masked a decline in earnings from carmaking caused by intensifying competition.
items.summary: A tax benefit boosted quarterly earnings, but that masked a decline in earnings from carmaking caused by intensifying competition.

items.title: Brad Stone Named Editor of Bloomberg Businessweek
items.content_html: Mr. Stone will take the helm as the 94-year-old magazine shifts from weekly to monthly publication.
items.summary: Mr. Stone will take the helm as the 94-year-old magazine shifts from weekly to monthly publication.

items.title: Shipping Costs Soar in Wake of Red Sea Attacks
items.content_html: Ships risking Houthi attacks must pay high insurance premiums, while vessels avoiding the region lose time going around Africa.
items.summary: Ships risking Houthi attacks must pay high insurance premiums, while vessels avoiding the region lose time going around Africa.

items.title: Katherine Maher Named C.E.O. of NPR
items.content_html: Ms. Maher was previously chief executive of the Wikimedia Foundation, a nonprofit that supports the online encyclopedia Wikipedia.
items.summary: Ms. Maher was previously chief executive of the Wikimedia Foundation, a nonprofit that supports the online encyclopedia Wikipedia.

items.title: White House Said to Delay Decision on CP2, a Liquid Natural Gas Export Terminal
items.content_html: Before deciding whether to approve it, the Energy Department will analyze the climate impacts of CP2, one of 17 proposed LNG export terminals.
items.summary: Before deciding whether to approve it, the Energy Department will analyze the climate impacts of CP2, one of 17 proposed LNG export terminals.

items.title: The News About the News Business Is Getting Grimmer
items.content_html: Mass layoffs, closures and reader fatigue are afflicting news organizations as Americans prepare for a consequential election year.
items.summary: Mass layoffs, closures and reader fatigue are afflicting news organizations as Americans prepare for a consequential election year.

author.name: Michael M. Grynbaum, John Koblin, Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson

items.summary: The aircraft maker’s customers are going public with their frustrations, hoping their tough comments will force the company to improve quality control and engineering.

items.title: Biden Receives U.A.W. Endorsement With Conference Speech

items.title: After New Hamphire, Business Braces for a Trump Nomination
items.content_html: Donald Trump cruised to victory in the state’s Republican primary, leaving anti-Trump donors and others to grapple with the reality of a near-certain nomination.
items.summary: Donald Trump cruised to victory in the state’s Republican primary, leaving anti-Trump donors and others to grapple with the reality of a near-certain nomination.

items.title: British Court Answers an Eternal Question: How Much Potato Does a Crisp Contain?
items.content_html: A snack company’s yearslong effort to protect the sanctity of its poppadom spuddered — er, sputtered — in a tax tribunal this month.
items.summary: A snack company’s yearslong effort to protect the sanctity of its poppadom spuddered — er, sputtered — in a tax tribunal this month.

items.title: The Sports Illustrated Cover, a Faded Canvas That Once Defined Sports

items.summary: It used to be the most coveted real estate in sports journalism. But its power to set the agenda disappeared along with its elite photographers.

items.title: Amid a Housing Crunch, Religious Groups Unlock Land to Build Homes
items.content_html: Faith-based organizations are unlocking their real estate to develop affordable housing, but they face challenges from reluctant local residents, wary lenders and strict zoning laws.
items.summary: Faith-based organizations are unlocking their real estate to develop affordable housing, but they face challenges from reluctant local residents, wary lenders and strict zoning laws.

items.title: Netflix is Said to License ‘Sex and the City’ From HBO
items.content_html: Media companies that had been reluctant to are increasingly offering shows to Netflix, which is pulling further ahead in the streaming wars.
items.summary: Media companies that had been reluctant to are increasingly offering shows to Netflix, which is pulling further ahead in the streaming wars.

items.title: German Rail Workers Strike Over Pay and Hours
items.content_html: The walkout, over pay and hours, is the most significant in years at the national train operator, which warned of a “massive reduction” in service.
items.summary: The walkout, over pay and hours, is the most significant in years at the national train operator, which warned of a “massive reduction” in service.

items.title: Delta Air Lines Boeing 757 Lost Nose Wheel Before Takeoff, F.A.A. Says

items.summary: The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating the latest troubling event involving a Boeing aircraft.

items.title: Is Royal Caribbean’s Icon of the Seas Cruise Ship Really Sustainable?
items.content_html: The newly christened Icon of the Seas is filled with energy-efficient technology. But some climate experts say the biggest challenge with a ship that can accommodate nearly 8,000 people is its size.
items.summary: The newly christened Icon of the Seas is filled with energy-efficient technology. But some climate experts say the biggest challenge with a ship that can accommodate nearly 8,000 people is its size.

items.title: Pastor Charged With Cryptocurrency Fraud Said God Told Him to Do It
items.content_html: In a civil action, prosecutors in Colorado said that a Denver pastor and his wife created and sold a cryptocurrency that was “practically worthless” and then pocketed more than $1 million.
items.summary: In a civil action, prosecutors in Colorado said that a Denver pastor and his wife created and sold a cryptocurrency that was “practically worthless” and then pocketed more than $1 million.

items.title: TurboTax Can No Longer Advertise Products as Free, F.T.C. Says
items.content_html: About two-thirds of taxpayers did not qualify for the free service. The disclaimers that it was not free for all were often “ineffective and often inconspicuous,” the Federal Trade Commission said.
items.summary: About two-thirds of taxpayers did not qualify for the free service. The disclaimers that it was not free for all were often “ineffective and often inconspicuous,” the Federal Trade Commission said.

items.title: Charles Osgood, Lyrical Newscaster on Radio and TV, Dies at 91
items.content_html: A familiar face on television as the host of “CBS Sunday Morning” from 1994 to 2016, he was also known for his “Osgood File” segments on CBS Radio, often delivered with humor and a rhyme.
items.summary: A familiar face on television as the host of “CBS Sunday Morning” from 1994 to 2016, he was also known for his “Osgood File” segments on CBS Radio, often delivered with humor and a rhyme.

items.title: Los Angeles Times to Slash Newsroom by Over 20%
items.content_html: The layoffs represent the biggest newsroom reduction since the biotech billionaire Patrick Soon-Shiong bought the company in 2018.
items.summary: The layoffs represent the biggest newsroom reduction since the biotech billionaire Patrick Soon-Shiong bought the company in 2018.

items.title: Climate Change Takes Center Stage in Economics

items.summary: With climate change affecting everything from household finances to electric grids, the profession is increasingly focused on how society can mitigate carbon emissions and cope with their impact.

items.title: Rising Markets Lift Hedge Funds to Huge Gains

items.summary: The 20 best-performing hedge funds made $67 billion in gains last year, a big jump from the year before.

items.title: Norby Walters, 91, Dies; Music and Sports Agent Who Ran Afoul of the Law

items.summary: He ran a highly successful booking agency, but his secret contacts with college athletes led to convictions (later reversed) for racketeering and fraud.

items.title: Florida State, 13-0, Snubbed By College Football Playoff Committee

items.summary: In sports, the best team doesn’t always win a championship, but it almost always gets an opportunity to try. Tell that to the 13-0 Florida State Seminoles.

items.title: His Team Was a Chaotic Punchline. Then He Found a New Spot in the Sport.

items.title: The ACC and Other Conferences Are Changing College Sports

items.title: After the Loss of a Son, a Football Coach Confronts a Terrible Truth

items.summary: Meiko Locksley was found to have had a degenerative brain disease often associated with football. His father, the head coach at Maryland, is still reckoning with the implications.

items.title: The Unusual Legal Agreement Behind ‘The Blind Side’

items.summary: Michael Oher says Sean and Leigh Anne Tuohy used their relationship with him to unfairly profit from his story. They have denied it.

items.title: How the Drama of ‘The Blind Side’ Helped Sports Fans Look Past Questions
items.content_html: “The Blind Side” played on sports fans’ penchant for too-tidy narratives, our columnist writes. A legal battle between the N.F.L. player and the family depicted in the film seeks to answer questions the dramatization looked past.
items.summary: “The Blind Side” played on sports fans’ penchant for too-tidy narratives, our columnist writes. A legal battle between the N.F.L. player and the family depicted in the film seeks to answer questions the dramatization looked past.

items.title: Michael Oher’s ‘Blind Side’ Lawsuit Shows Strains in Depictions of Black Athletes

items.summary: Michael Oher has long criticized the feel-good Hollywood version of his life as a struggling high school football player. His lawsuit against the family that took him in questions their relationship.

items.title: The Big Ten Lands Oregon and Washington, Leaving the Pac-12 Bereft
items.content_html: The Big Ten booms to 18 schools with the move, powered by TV money, and the once-great Pac-12 dwindles to four after three more schools leave for the Big 12.
items.summary: The Big Ten booms to 18 schools with the move, powered by TV money, and the once-great Pac-12 dwindles to four after three more schools leave for the Big 12.

items.title: Abuse and Racism Accusations Bring ‘#MeToo Moment’ to Northwestern

items.summary: In lawsuits, former athletes accuse the sports program of having a pervasive culture of hazing and sexual abuse, and two coaches have been fired. Lawyers say more athletes may come forward.

items.title: University of Tennessee Fined Millions for Cash Payments to Athletes
items.content_html: The N.C.A.A. said Tennessee had a culture of wrongful payments to athletes, including cash for hotels, meals and car payments, among other things. The university was fined $8 million but avoided a postseason ban.
items.summary: The N.C.A.A. said Tennessee had a culture of wrongful payments to athletes, including cash for hotels, meals and car payments, among other things. The university was fined $8 million but avoided a postseason ban.

items.title: San Diego State Opts to Stay in the Mountain West Conference

items.summary: San Diego State had to make a decision about whether to leave the Mountain West Conference. It stayed put, but a move to the Pac-12 still beckons.

items.title: Transfer Portal Shows the Latest Revolving Door in College Football
items.content_html: Colorado has numerous scholarships available after a change in its coaching staff, serving as one of many examples of how the transfer portal has created a market similar to professional free agency.
items.summary: Colorado has numerous scholarships available after a change in its coaching staff, serving as one of many examples of how the transfer portal has created a market similar to professional free agency.

items.title: Georgia’s Jalen Carter Avoids Jail Time for Role in Fatal Crash

items.summary: Carter, projected as a top-five pick in the N.F.L. draft, pleaded no contest to two misdemeanor charges and will serve 12 months of probation.

items.title: Georgia’s Jalen Carter Accused in Car Crash That Killed Two People

items.summary: The police said that Carter, projected as a top-5 pick in the N.F.L. draft, had been involved in a crash that killed a Georgia teammate and a team staff member.

items.title: Devin Willock and UGA Staff Member Killed in Car Crash

items.title: My Favorite Way to Watch College Football: D.I.Y. Hype Videos

items.title: T.C.U., Confronting Georgia, Spirals on National Title Stage

items.title: Georgia, With a Clear Rout, Shows Gap From Rest of College Football

items.title: With Relief Room, a Fan Pays Tribute to Phillies Relievers

items.summary: With the Relief Room, a Phillies fan has created an over-the-top shrine to baseball’s most unsung players. It is in his downstairs bathroom.

items.title: Abuela, Chef, Boss: Vladimir Guerrero Jr.’s Grandmother Feeds the Majors

items.summary: For about two decades, Altagracia Alvino has lived with and cooked for her baseball-playing offspring — as well as their teammates and opponents.

items.title: How Tim Flannery, the Giants Coach, Got Back to Writing Songs

items.summary: Tim Flannery’s rollicking life as an athlete and a musician was nearly cut short by a staph infection. But one of baseball’s most unlikely characters found his way back.

items.title: How Joey Votto of the Reds Became a Social Media Star

items.title: How the Emerald Ash Borer Took Ash Bats Out of Major League Baseball
items.content_html: Invasive insects and batter preferences have led to the elimination of the wood that dominated the sport for generations. There may not be a single ash bat used in this postseason.
items.summary: Invasive insects and batter preferences have led to the elimination of the wood that dominated the sport for generations. There may not be a single ash bat used in this postseason.

items.title: How John DeMarsico Made SNY’s Mets Broadcasts Go Viral

items.summary: SNY already had some of the best announcers in baseball. John DeMarsico, the network’s director, has made every game feel like a trip to the movies.

items.title: Nashville Stars Honor Baseball’s Past by Focusing on the Future

items.summary: Named after a team from the Negro leagues, the Nashville Stars give young players, Black and white, passion and purpose in the game.

items.title: Gil Hodges and the Christmas Visit That Changed Everything
items.content_html: After a long wait, Gil Hodges was elected to the Hall of Fame. For one of the many people whose lives he helped change with community work, Hodges was already a legend.
items.summary: After a long wait, Gil Hodges was elected to the Hall of Fame. For one of the many people whose lives he helped change with community work, Hodges was already a legend.

items.title: Why Does Oswaldo Cabrera Wear a Pearl Necklace?
items.content_html: Oswaldo Cabrera has had highlights at multiple positions in his first week in the majors. The only constants have been his enthusiasm and his atypical accessory.
items.summary: Oswaldo Cabrera has had highlights at multiple positions in his first week in the majors. The only constants have been his enthusiasm and his atypical accessory.

items.title: Bud Harrelson, Shortstop for ‘Miracle Mets’ of 1969, Dies at 79
items.content_html: An outstanding fielder, he helped the team win the World Series that year and reach another in 1973. He stayed with the Mets as a coach and, briefly, manager.
items.summary: An outstanding fielder, he helped the team win the World Series that year and reach another in 1973. He stayed with the Mets as a coach and, briefly, manager.

items.title: Ohtani’s Contract Goes Beyond Dollars and Sense
items.content_html: The Los Angeles Dodgers are betting $700 million that Shohei Ohtani can deliver championships and help increase revenue. But the economics of sports can be fickle.
items.summary: The Los Angeles Dodgers are betting $700 million that Shohei Ohtani can deliver championships and help increase revenue. But the economics of sports can be fickle.

items.title: Baseball Has Grown in Bogotá, Colombia, Thanks to Venezuelan Migrants
items.content_html: In a Bogotá league, Venezuelans who fled their homeland have carried on their culture in a country surrounded by soccer — and have built a support system. “It’s like having a piece of Venezuela here.”
items.summary: In a Bogotá league, Venezuelans who fled their homeland have carried on their culture in a country surrounded by soccer — and have built a support system. “It’s like having a piece of Venezuela here.”

items.title: Willie Hernández, Relief Pitcher Who Had a Banner 1984, Dies at 69
items.content_html: He was voted the American League’s Most Valuable Player and won its Cy Young Award in a championship season with the Detroit Tigers. “It’s unbelievable,” he said.
items.summary: He was voted the American League’s Most Valuable Player and won its Cy Young Award in a championship season with the Detroit Tigers. “It’s unbelievable,” he said.

items.title: A’s Will Finally Turn Out the Lights on Pro Sports in Oakland
items.content_html: With baseball owners approving the Athletics’ move to Las Vegas, some see the departure as the death of the working-class sports fan.
items.summary: With baseball owners approving the Athletics’ move to Las Vegas, some see the departure as the death of the working-class sports fan.

items.title: Peter Seidler, Big-Spending San Diego Padres Owner, Dies at 63
items.content_html: Under his leadership, the team’s payroll grew to one of the largest in Major League Baseball. But a championship proved elusive.
items.summary: Under his leadership, the team’s payroll grew to one of the largest in Major League Baseball. But a championship proved elusive.
